marketNews.title: Poultry 2Q25: Pressured Broiler and DOC Prices
marketNews.content:
Japfa Comfeed Indonesia (JPFA), Charoen Pokphand Indonesia (CPIN), and Malindo Feedmill (MAIN) reported pressured performance during 2Q25 as broiler and DOC (day-old chick) prices fell sharply while demand has not recovered. JPFA was the best performer in the quarter, whereas CPIN and MAIN suffered significant corrections, even posting operating losses in some lines. This result is consistent with our previous outlook (https://stockbit.com/post/18469022) that the absence of the festive (Lebaran) season and the historical effect of the Suro month could depress poultry prices.

1. JPFA: Net profit declined in 2Q25 (-18% QoQ, -32% YoY), resulting in a 1H25 decline of -16% YoY and below expectations (43%/40% of the 2025F Stockbit/Consensus estimate).
2. CPIN: Net profit collapsed in 2Q25 (-76% QoQ, -66% YoY), making 1H25 growth +7% YoY and below expectations (42%/45% of the 2025F Stockbit/Consensus estimate).
3. MAIN: Recorded its first quarterly loss since 1Q23 and a -91% YoY decline in net profit for 1H25.

Key highlights of the three issuers' 2Q25 performance:

Broiler segment: Only JPFA remained profitable. JPFA posted operating profit of IDR 292 billion in the Broiler segment in 2Q25 (+14% QoQ) even though the broiler price fell to IDR 16,326 per kg (-15% QoQ). CPIN, historically the strongest, recorded an operating loss of IDR 130 billion, while MAIN posted an operating loss of IDR 77 billion.

DOC segment: Prices fell to IDR 4,196 per bird (-24% QoQ), causing all three issuers to record operating losses in this segment in 2Q25. JPFA was the most resilient with a loss of IDR 13 billion, followed by MAIN with a loss of IDR 45 billion, while CPIN suffered the deepest loss of IDR 197 billion.

Processed Chicken segment: The segment was also pressured. Although JPFA and MAIN showed year-over-year revenue growth in 2Q25, JPFA's operating profit fell to IDR 79 billion (-36% YoY) and MAIN returned to a loss of IDR 12 billion (vs. a loss of IDR 14 billion in 2Q24). CPIN saw revenue decline -17% QoQ and operating profit drop sharply to IDR 46 billion after having posted a profit of IDR 331 billion in 1Q25.

Key Takeaway: With poultry prices still significantly unrecovered amid weak demand, we assess that accelerated government procurement is needed to boost demand and support a price recovery in 2H25. In the medium to long term, the implementation of a free nutritious meals program could structurally increase demand if it incorporates chicken products.

Since the earnings releases of CPIN and JPFA on Thursday (31 July) afternoon, JPFA's share price rose +5.31% and CPIN fell -3.25% on Friday (1 August). MAIN, which released its results on Thursday (31 July) morning, saw its share price decline -8.8% by Friday (1 August). The outperformance of JPFA's share price can be attributed to its relatively more resilient performance compared with peers. MAIN will hold an earnings call on Friday (8 August) morning.

marketNews.title: Other hot topics you need to know
marketNews.content:
1. BPS reported that the consumer price index (CPI) inflation in Indonesia reached 2.37% year-on-year in July 2025 (vs. June 2025: 1.87% YoY), higher than the consensus expectation of 2.24% YoY and marking the highest annual inflation since June 2024. The expenditure groups driving inflation were 'food, beverages and tobacco' (3.75% YoY) and 'personal care and other services' (9% YoY), contributing 1.08 percentage points and 0.57 percentage points respectively. Monthly inflation was 0.3% MoM (vs. June 2025: 0.19% MoM). Core inflation in July 2025 eased to 2.32% YoY (vs. June 2025: 2.37% YoY), below the consensus expectation of 2.37% YoY.
2. S&P Global reported that Indonesia's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) stood at 49.2 in July 2025 (vs. June 2025: 46.9), indicating a continued contraction in factory activity for the fourth consecutive month. Output decline slowed compared with the previous four months, but foreign demand returned to contraction after a brief stabilization in June 2025. Manufacturers remain optimistic about the next year, driven by expectations of economic improvement and lower raw material prices. However, optimism fell sharply compared with June 2025 and is the weakest since the PMI survey began in April 2012, amid concerns over US tariffs and weak consumer purchasing power. The July 2025 PMI survey was conducted between 10-24 July 2025, with almost all responses submitted before the announcement of the US-Indonesia trade agreement on 22 July 2025.
3. S&P Global reported that China's manufacturing PMI fell to 49.5 in July 2025 (vs. June 2025: 50.4), below the consensus expectation of 50.2. The decline was driven by a second consecutive drop in production since October 2023, amid a continued contraction in new export orders for the fourth month, with a faster decline than in June 2025. Overall, producer optimism improved compared with June 2025, though still below historical averages.
4. BPS reported that foreign tourist arrivals (wisman) to Indonesia reached approximately 1.4 million in June 2025 (+18.2% YoY, +8.4% MoM). This resulted in total foreign visitor arrivals of about 7.1 million in the first half of 2025, a +9.4% YoY increase, representing 44-50% of the 2025 government target of 14-16 million visitors.

tickerNews.title: JPFA 2Q25 performance
tickerNews.content: JPFA net profit fell in 2Q25 (-18% QoQ, -32% YoY), resulting in a 1H25 decline of -16% YoY and below expectations (43%/40% of the 2025F Stockbit/Consensus estimate). JPFA recorded operating profit of IDR 292 billion in the Broiler segment in 2Q25 (+14% QoQ) while the broiler price dropped to IDR 16,326 per kg (-15% QoQ). In the DOC segment JPFA was the most resilient with a loss of IDR 13 billion. In the Processed Chicken segment operating profit fell to IDR 79 billion (-36% YoY). JPFA's share price rose +5.31% on Friday (1 August).

tickerNews.title: CPIN 2Q25 performance
tickerNews.content: CPIN net profit collapsed in 2Q25 (-76% QoQ, -66% YoY), making 1H25 growth +7% YoY and below expectations (42%/45% of the 2025F Stockbit/Consensus estimate). CPIN recorded an operating loss of IDR 130 billion in the Broiler segment and a loss of IDR 197 billion in the DOC segment. In the Processed Chicken segment CPIN's operating profit dropped to IDR 46 billion after having posted a profit of IDR 331 billion in 1Q25. CPIN's share price fell -3.25% on Friday (1 August).

tickerNews.title: MAIN 2Q25 performance
tickerNews.content: MAIN recorded its first quarterly loss since 1Q23 and a -91% YoY decline in net profit for 1H25. MAIN posted an operating loss of IDR 77 billion in the Broiler segment and a loss of IDR 45 billion in the DOC segment. In the Processed Chicken segment MAIN returned to a loss of IDR 12 billion (vs. a loss of IDR 14 billion in 2Q24). MAIN's share price declined -8.8% by Friday (1 August).

tickerNews.title: TLKM 1H25 net profit and operating results
tickerNews.content: Telkom Indonesia recorded net profit of IDR 5.1 trillion in 2Q25 (-10% YoY, -11% QoQ). This resulted in 1H25 net profit of IDR 11 trillion (-7% YoY), below expectations (46% of the 2025F consensus estimate). Operating profit in 2Q25 fell to IDR 9.7 trillion (-7% YoY, -4% QoQ), leading to 1H25 operating profit of IDR 19.9 trillion (-8% YoY), also below expectations (46% of the 2025F consensus). Mobile segment subscribers fell to 158.4 million (-0.9% YoY, -0.2% QoQ) and ARPU declined to IDR 41,200 (-8% YoY, -3% QoQ). TLKM explained that the decline was expected as part of its strategy to reduce churn loops while disciplining renewal package pricing.

tickerNews.title: NCKL 1H25 net profit and margin improvement
tickerNews.content: Trimegah Bangun Persada reported net profit of IDR 2.4 trillion in 2Q25 (+47.6% QoQ, +35.5% YoY), leading to 1H25 net profit of IDR 4.1 trillion (+46.2% YoY), surpassing expectations (59.6% of the 2025F consensus estimate). Quarterly revenue fell -2.2% QoQ, but net profit grew due to a reduction in cost of goods sold (-13.9% QoQ) and operating expenses (-16.4% QoQ), raising gross margin to 37.9% (vs. 29.5% in 1Q25) and operating margin to 33.9% (vs. 24.8% in 1Q25). The lower cost of goods sold was driven by inventory valuation changes, resulting in a lower average selling cost in 2Q25. Associate income also rose +93.7% QoQ, mainly from higher profit shares from Halmahera Persada Legend (+122% QoQ) and PT Karunia Permai Sentosa (+788% QoQ).

tickerNews.title: SIDO 1H25 net profit and revenue recovery
tickerNews.content: Industri Jamu dan Farmasi Sido Muncul reported net profit of IDR 368 billion in 2Q25 (+69% YoY, +58% QoQ), resulting in 1H25 net profit of IDR 600 billion (-1% YoY), exceeding expectations (53% of the 2025F consensus estimate). The annual profit surge was driven by a significant revenue recovery (+23% YoY, +32% QoQ), although 1H25 revenue fell -4% YoY. Gross margin improved to 60.5% in 2Q25 (vs. 52.3% in 1Q25 and 56.8% in 2Q24). Operating expenses fell -18% YoY in 2Q25, lifting operating profit by +73% YoY in 2Q25, although 1H25 operating profit still declined -4% YoY due to weak performance in 1Q25.

tickerNews.title: INTP 1H25 net profit and margin dynamics
tickerNews.content: Indocement Tunggal Prakarsa reported net profit of IDR 284 billion in 2Q25 (+44% YoY, +35% QoQ), leading to 1H25 net profit of IDR 495 billion (+14% YoY), roughly in line with expectations (26% of the 2025F consensus estimate versus a 29% average over the past two years). Gross margin increased by 250 basis points YoY in 2Q25 and by 90 basis points YoY in 1H25, supported by a 2% YoY increase in average selling price. The company said the price increase was driven by a higher proportion of bag cement in the product mix, but it does not plan aggressive price adjustments. Gross margin was also helped by a 4% YoY reduction in cost of goods sold per ton in 2Q25, while cost per ton was flat in 1H25. Operating expenses were relatively stable in 2Q25, resulting in a 2% YoY decline in operating expenses over 1H25. Revenue was flat in 2Q25 (+0.4% YoY) and declined -1% YoY in 1H25, with sales volume flat in 2Q25 (+1% YoY) and decreasing in 1H25 (-3% YoY).

tickerNews.title: PTBA 1H25 net profit and margin improvement
tickerNews.content: Bukit Asam reported net profit of IDR 442 billion in 2Q25 (+12.8% QoQ, -64.4% YoY), resulting in 1H25 net profit of IDR 833 billion (-59% YoY), below expectations (22.8% of the 2025F consensus estimate). Quarterly profit increase was driven by revenue growth (+5.4% QoQ) and an operating margin rise to 4.8% (vs. 3.5% in 1Q25). PTBA also saw improvements in gross and operating margins as cost of goods sold increased more moderately (+4.3% QoQ) while operating expenses fell -0.7% QoQ.

tickerNews.title: PTRO signs conditional acquisition agreement
tickerNews.content: Petrosea announced that it has signed a conditional agreement to acquire all shares of HBS PNG Limited, a Papua New Guinea mining, construction, and heavy equipment services company, for a total transaction value of USD 25.8 million. PTRO explained that the acquisition is part of its strategy to expand overseas and diversify into the gold mineral sector.

tickerNews.title: HEAL share purchase by Astra International
tickerNews.content: Shareholders of Medikaloka Hermina, Astra International (ASII), purchased approximately 313 million HEAL shares at an average price of IDR 1,572 per share between 25-31 July 2025. The total transaction value was about IDR 493 billion and was executed through its subsidiary PT Astra Healthcare Indonesia. After the transaction, Astra's direct and indirect ownership in HEAL increased from approximately 7.96% to about 10%.

tickerNews.title: INDY joint venture terminal agreement
tickerNews.content: Indika Energy announced that its joint venture entity, PT Batu Ampar Container Terminal, has signed a cooperation agreement with PT Batam Terminal Petikemas to become a strategic partner in operating the Batu Ampar Container Terminal in Batam for 30 years. The estimated value of the agreement is USD 85 million. PT Batu Ampar Container Terminal is a joint venture between INDY's subsidiary PT Interport Sarana Infrastruktur Indonesia (25% ownership) and ICTSI Middle East DMCC (75% ownership).

tickerNews.title: TAPG interim dividend announcement
tickerNews.content: Triputra Agro Persada plans to distribute an interim dividend for fiscal year 2025 amounting to approximately IDR 774.2 billion or IDR 39 per share, indicating a dividend yield of about 2.6% as of Friday (1 August). The cum-date is on the regular market and the ex-date is 11 August 2025, with payment scheduled for 29 August 2025.

tickerNews.title: NICL share purchase by Christopher Sumasto Tjia
tickerNews.content: The controlling shareholder of PAM Mineral, Christopher Sumasto Tjia, bought 7.8 million NICL shares at an average price of IDR 1,118 per share on 31 July 2025. The total transaction value was about IDR 8.7 billion. After the transaction, Christopher Sumasto Tjia's direct ownership in NICL increased from 0.38% to approximately 0.45%.
